DataElement.preferredName: Prior Aerodigestive Tract Cancer Site Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The free-text used to describe the position in relation to the surroundings of a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues in the anatomic structures forming the upper respiratory tract and upper part of the digestive tract.  They include the oral cavity, sinonasal tract, pharynx, pyriform sinus, larynx, trachea, and esophagus.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information pertaining to tumors composed of atypical neoplastic often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues a person has experienced in the anatomic structures forming the upper respiratory tract and upper part of the digestive tract.  They include the oral cavity, sinonasal tract, pharynx, pyriform sinus, larynx, trachea, and esophagus. and tumor composed of atypical neoplastic,

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:Anatomic structures forming the upper respiratory tract and upper part of the digestive tract.  They include the oral cavity, sinonasal tract, pharynx, pyriform sinus, larynx, trachea, and esophagus.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Anatomic structures forming the upper respiratory tract and upper part of the digestive tract. They include the oral cavity, sinonasal tract, pharynx, pyriform sinus, larynx, trachea, and esophagus.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

Concepts.definition: Anatomic structures forming the upper respiratory tract and upper part of the digestive tract. They include the oral cavity, sinonasal tract, pharynx, pyriform sinus, larynx, trachea, and esophagus.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A position in relation to its surroundings.
